bgc:general.bgc:title: Aggregated data of radar, Airborne Laser Scanning, and biodiversity measures on all forest EPs (2006-2018) used in "Radar vision for mapping forest biodiversity from space"

bgc:methodology.bgc:introduction: This dataset is an aggregated data (2006-2018) of environmental variables (independent variables) and different facets of biodiversity meausres (response variables) on all forest EPs used in "Radar vision for mapping forest biodiversity from space", submitted to Nature Communications. In environmental variables, two remote sensing techniques, spaceborne radar and airborne laser scanning, were employed to derive forest structure. In biodiversity measure, species composition, species richness, and phylogenetic diversity of 12 functional groups were included. To include a comprehensive gradient of forest structure, the data collected in the course of the Exploratories (150 plots) was supplemented by two further projects located in the Steigerwald (69 Plots) and in the Bavarian Forest (BIOKLIM, 244 Plots).

bgc:measurements.bgc:theory:
1. Airborne laser scanning (ALS) ALS is a very tangible sensor technology, and the three-dimensional (3-D) insight it provides has led to a number of advances in animal ecology and biodiversity conservation.
2. Radar Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) data are a prime candidate to meet the demands for ecologically meaningful information on vegetation structure from space from regional to global scales. A big advantage of SAR is the ability to penetrate clouds, making it a suitable technique also for regions with almost constant cloud coverage, such as the tropics or mountain areas. C-band SAR is sensitive to vegetation structures and is likely to be scattered from elements within the canopy of trees. The launch of the Sentinel-1 mission – a constellation of two C-band SAR satellites – by the European Space Agency in 2014 and 2016 has revolutionised SAR remote sensing through their unprecedented combination of high spatial resolution (5 – 20 m), high revisit frequencies (5 – 10 days), complete geographic coverage and last but not least: an open-access distribution policy.
3. Biodiversity measures We separated functional groups based on taxonomy and derived the assemblage composition per functional group by NMDS (Non-metric Multidimensional Scaling) using presence-absence data. We counted the number of observed species in each plot and log-transformed it for calculating species richness. Additionally, we calculated the standardized effect size of mean phylogenetic distance, as phylogenetic diversity has become influential for understanding ecosystem functioning associated with the assemblage communities and has been used as a proxy for functional diversity.
Please see more details in Bae et al. (2019)
bgc:measurements.bgc:type:
Analysis of original data. The data set comprises aggregated data of original species data per plot as well as environmental data (based on radar and ALS).
Original data lists:
1. Species data
1.1. Exploratories (BExIS datasets): 20826; Vegetation Records for Forest EPs, 2009-2016; version 1.4.5 4460; Lichen diversity in forests (2007-2008); version 1.11.14 4141; Bryophyte diversity in relationship to forest management types in forests (2007-2008); version 1.6.8 18547; Deadwood inhabiting fungi presence absence (2010, all forest EPs); version 1.2.2 16868; Window and ground traps on forest EPs in 2008 subset Araneae; version 1.1.3 16866; Window and ground traps on forest EPs in 2008 subset Coleoptera; version 1.1.3 21446; Bird survey data 2008; version 3.1.4 21447; Bird survey data 2009; version 3.1.2 21448; Bird survey data 2010; version 3.1.3 19848; Bat activity in all Exploratories, summer 2008, using acoustic monitoring; version 1.1.4 19849; Bat activity in all Exploratories, summer 2009, using acoustic monitoring; version 1.1.4 19850; Bat activity in all Exploratories, summer 2010, using acoustic monitoring; version 1.1.5
1.2. Steigerwald-Project Fungi: Roth, N. et al. (2019) Arthropods: Doerfler, I. et al. (2018), Roth, N. et al. (2019) and further, unpublished data which have been provided by Jörg Müller
1.3. BIOKLIM-Project Plants: Bässler, C. et al. (2010a) Bryophytes: Raabe, S. et al. (2010) Lichens: Moning, C. et al. (2009) Fungi: Bässler, C. et al. (2010b) Arthropods: Müller, J. & Brandl, R. (2009) Birds: Müller, J. et al. (2009) Bats: Müller, J. et al. (2012)
and further, unpublished data which have been provided by Jörg Müller
To gain comparable species data across projects and regions, for each region only the data of year closest to the LiDAR-flights was chosen. For each plot, species richness was summed over the whole collection period.
2. Environmental data 25246; Synthetic Aperture Radar (Sentinel-1) metrics on all forest EPs, 2016; version 1.1.2 BExIS datasets of ALS data soon to be uploaded.

bgc:equipment.bgc:instruments: 1. Airborne laser scanning (ALS): Riegl Q560/VQ780i 2. Radar: Sentinel-1 mission 3. Biodiversity assessments: Pettersson D 1000x ultrasound detector (Pettersson Electronic AG, Uppsala, Sweden) Batcorder 2.0 bat detector (ecoObs GmbH, Nurnberg, Germany) Observations by hearing & sight tape measure, knife, pencil & eye 12V, 15W super-actinic light tubes, bucket and chloroform For more details see Supplmentary methods S1.2 in Bae et al. (2019)
bgc:equipment.bgc:procedures: For details, see metadata of listed original data and Methods and Supplmentary methods S1.2 in Bae et al (2019)

bgc:data.bgc:manipulations:
1. Biodiversity measures based on species data Methods, grain and timeframe for species sampling - although standardized within the projects - differs between projects, though in various extent. In order to gain comparable estimates of biodiversity measures, data had to be of cropped to a comparable extent and, in parts, to equally determinable species sets. Manipulations on the original Species Data compiled in the Exploratories, the Steigerwald and BIOKLIM: Only species identified to species level were counted to gain comparable results across projects. An exception to this were in bats the sonotypes "Myotis branditii/mystacinus" and "Plecotus", which comprise two species each, but which have not been determined to species level in any project. Prior to analysis, differences in species composition were visually checked using NMDS. Plots, which lead to stress values of nearly zero were removed as outliers. Arthropods For Arthropods, Plot HEW34 has been excluded from the analysis as it has been repeatedly destroyed by boars. Also, in ALB, HAI and SCH species collected in April were excluded, as not all Plots have been covered in this month and only "Priority 1"-Samples were used to ensure an equal trap number across projects. The plots T3_4 and T2_34 (BIOKLIM) were excluded from analysis. Coleoptera were subdivided into necrophagous, phytophagous, saproxylic and carabid beetles. For spiders, the plots T4_47, T4_75 and T3_10 (all BIOKLIM) were removed as outliers. For carabid beetles, the plots T1_27, T1_34 and T1_57 (BIOKLIM) were removed as outliers. For fungi, we only included wood-inhabiting fungi. Because the fungal communities showed extreme differences between the projects, which was unlikely to be based on regional differences alone but rather an effect of the determinability of cryptic species, data cropped to a list of species which are equally determinable according to a specialist (CB). For instance, crustean species were not included. For lichens, we only included epiphytic lichens. Concerning the calculation of phylogenetic diversity, see details in Methods and Supplmentary methods S2 in Bae et al. (2019)
2. Environmental data (radar and ALS metrics) All the environmental variables (except heterogeneity indices including standardized deviation, dissimilarity, and entropy) were averaged within each 1 ha plot. The heterogeneity indices, i.e., standardized deviation, dissimilarity, and entropy, was calculated with window size of 9 by 9 pixels, i.e. 0.81 ha, to consider variability, contrast, and orderliness of the corresponding metrics within each plot Foliage height diversity (LiD_FHD) was calculated by the three classes of canopy, understory and regeneration layers.

bgc:variable.bgc:name: Explrtr
bgc:variable.bgc:description: Plot name type 1 (e.g. AEW01)

bgc:variable.bgc:name: Explrtr2
bgc:variable.bgc:description: Plot name type2 (e.g. AEW1)

bgc:variable.bgc:name: Region
bgc:variable.bgc:description: Forest region names

bgc:variable.bgc:name: LiD_H_MEAN
bgc:variable.bgc:description: Mean Canopy Height (based on point height above ground) from ALS (labeled as LiD hereafter)

bgc:variable.bgc:name: LiD_H_MAX
bgc:variable.bgc:description: Maximum Canopy Height (based on point height above ground) from ALS

bgc:variable.bgc:name: LiD_H_SD
bgc:variable.bgc:description: Standard Deviation of Canopy Height (based on point height above ground) from ALS

bgc:variable.bgc:name: LiD_H_VAR_COEF
bgc:variable.bgc:description: Coefficient of Variation of Canopy Height (based on point height above ground) from ALS

bgc:variable.bgc:name: LiD_PR_CANUND
bgc:variable.bgc:description: Penetration rate of canopy vegetation layer and understory layer from ALS

bgc:variable.bgc:name: LiD_PR_CAN
bgc:variable.bgc:description: Penetration rate of canopy vegetation layer (redirects to BE_RD_CAN) (based on point height above ground) from ALS

bgc:variable.bgc:name: LiD_PR_REG
bgc:variable.bgc:description: Penetration rate of regeneration vegetation layer (based on point height above ground) from ALS

bgc:variable.bgc:name: LiD_PR_UND
bgc:variable.bgc:description: Penetration rate of understory vegetation layer (based on point height above ground) from ALS

bgc:variable.bgc:name: LiD_FHD
bgc:variable.bgc:description: Foliage Height Diversity (based on point height above ground) from ALS

bgc:variable.bgc:name: LiD_gap_total_edge_length
bgc:variable.bgc:description: Total edge length of gaps from ALS

bgc:variable.bgc:name: LiD_gap_total_area
bgc:variable.bgc:description: Total area of gaps from ALS

bgc:variable.bgc:name: LiD_chm_surface_ratio
bgc:variable.bgc:description: area ratio of CHM raster pixels from ALS

bgc:variable.bgc:name: LiD_chm_height_sd
bgc:variable.bgc:description: standard deviation of surface above ground (based on CHM raster pixels) from ALS

bgc:variable.bgc:name: S1_diff_VH_VV_dissimilarity
bgc:variable.bgc:description: Dissimilarity of S1_diff_VH_VV with neighbourhood pixels from radar (labeled as S1 hereafter) (used BExIS Id: 25246 v1.1.2 v1.1.2)

bgc:variable.bgc:name: S1_diff_VH_VV_entropy
bgc:variable.bgc:description: Entropy of S1_diff_VH_VV with neighbourhood pixels from radar (used BExIS Id: 25246 v1.1.2)

bgc:variable.bgc:name: S1_ratio_VV_VH_dissimilarity

bgc:variable.bgc:name: specnumbers_Bats
bgc:variable.bgc:description: The log-transformed number of observed bat species (used BExIS Ids: 19848 v1.1.4, 19849 v1.1.4, 19850 v1.1.5; used paper: Müller, J. et al. (2012))

bgc:variable.bgc:name: ses_mpd_Bats
bgc:variable.bgc:description: The standardized effect size of mean phylogenetic distance of bat assemblage (used BExIS Ids: 19848 v1.1.4, 19849 v1.1.4, 19850 v1.1.5; used paper: Müller, J. et al. (2012))

bgc:variable.bgc:name: NMDS1_Bats
bgc:variable.bgc:description: The first axes of bat species composition based on NMDS ordination scores (used BExIS Ids: 19848 v1.1.4, 19849 v1.1.4, 19850 v1.1.5; used paper: Müller, J. et al. (2012))

bgc:variable.bgc:name: NMDS2_Bats
bgc:variable.bgc:description: The second axes of bat species composition based on NMDS ordination scores (used BExIS Ids: 19848 v1.1.4, 19849 v1.1.4, 19850 v1.1.5; used paper: Müller, J. et al. (2012))

bgc:variable.bgc:name: specnumbers_Birds
bgc:variable.bgc:description: The log-transformed number of observed bird species (used BExIS Ids: 21446 v3.1.4, 21447 v3.1.2, 21448 v3.1.3; used paper: Müller, J. et al. (2009))

bgc:variable.bgc:name: ses_mpd_Birds
bgc:variable.bgc:description: The standardized effect size of mean phylogenetic distance of bird assemblage (used BExIS Ids: 21446 v3.1.4, 21447 v3.1.2, 21448 v3.1.3; used paper: Müller, J. et al. (2009))

bgc:variable.bgc:name: NMDS1_Birds
bgc:variable.bgc:description: The first axes of bird species composition based on NMDS ordination scores (used BExIS Ids: 21446 v3.1.4, 21447 v3.1.2, 21448 v3.1.3; used paper: Müller, J. et al. (2009))

bgc:variable.bgc:name: NMDS2_Birds
bgc:variable.bgc:description: The second axes of bird species composition based on NMDS ordination scores (used BExIS Ids: 21446 v3.1.4, 21447 v3.1.2, 21448 v3.1.3; used paper: Müller, J. et al. (2009))

bgc:variable.bgc:name: NMDS3_Birds
bgc:variable.bgc:description: The third axes of bird species composition based on NMDS ordination scores (used BExIS Ids: 21446 v3.1.4, 21447 v3.1.2, 21448 v3.1.3; used paper: Müller, J. et al. (2009))

bgc:variable.bgc:name: specnumbers_Necrophagous
bgc:variable.bgc:description: The log-transformed number of observed necrophagous beetle species (used BExIS Id: 16866 v1.1.3; used papers: Müller, J. & Brandl, R. (2009), Doerfler, I. et al. (2018), Roth, N. et al. (2019))

bgc:variable.bgc:name: ses_mpd_Necrophagous

bgc:variable.bgc:name: NMDS2_Necrophagous

bgc:variable.bgc:name: NMDS3_Necrophagous

bgc:variable.bgc:description: The first axes of saproxylic beetle species composition based on NMDS ordination scores (used BExIS Id: 16866 v1.1.3; used papers: Müller, J. & Brandl, R. (2009), Doerfler, I. et al. (2018), Roth, N. et al. (2019))

bgc:variable.bgc:name: NMDS2_Saproxylic
bgc:variable.bgc:description: The second axes of saproxylic beetle species composition based on NMDS ordination scores (used BExIS Id: 16866 v1.1.3; used papers: Müller, J. & Brandl, R. (2009), Doerfler, I. et al. (2018), Roth, N. et al. (2019))

bgc:variable.bgc:name: NMDS3_Saproxylic
bgc:variable.bgc:description: The third axes of saproxylic beetle species composition based on NMDS ordination scores (used BExIS Id: 16866 v1.1.3; used papers: Müller, J. & Brandl, R. (2009), Doerfler, I. et al. (2018), Roth, N. et al. (2019))

bgc:variable.bgc:name: specnumbers_Moths
bgc:variable.bgc:description: The log-transformed number of observed moth species

bgc:variable.bgc:name: ses_mpd_Moths
bgc:variable.bgc:description: The standardized effect size of mean phylogenetic distance of moth assemblage

bgc:variable.bgc:name: NMDS1_Moths
bgc:variable.bgc:description: The first axes of moth species composition based on NMDS ordination scores

bgc:variable.bgc:name: NMDS2_Moths
bgc:variable.bgc:description: The second axes of moth species composition based on NMDS ordination scores

bgc:variable.bgc:name: specnumbers_Phytophagous
bgc:variable.bgc:description: The log-transformed number of observed phytophagous beetle species (used BExIS Id: 16866 v1.1.3; used papers: Müller, J. & Brandl, R. (2009), Doerfler, I. et al. (2018), Roth, N. et al. (2019))

bgc:variable.bgc:name: ses_mpd_Phytophagous
bgc:variable.bgc:description: The standardized effect size of mean phylogenetic distance of phytophagous beetle assemblage (used BExIS Id: 16866 v1.1.3; used papers: Müller, J. & Brandl, R. (2009), Doerfler, I. et al. (2018), Roth, N. et al. (2019))

bgc:variable.bgc:name: NMDS1_Phytophagous
bgc:variable.bgc:description: The first axes of phytophagous beetle species composition based on NMDS ordination scores (used BExIS Id: 16866 v1.1.3; used papers: Müller, J. & Brandl, R. (2009), Doerfler, I. et al. (2018), Roth, N. et al. (2019))

bgc:variable.bgc:name: NMDS2_Phytophagous
bgc:variable.bgc:description: The second axes of phytophagous beetle species composition based on NMDS ordination scores (used BExIS Id: 16866 v1.1.3; used papers: Müller, J. & Brandl, R. (2009), Doerfler, I. et al. (2018), Roth, N. et al. (2019))

bgc:variable.bgc:name: NMDS3_Phytophagous
bgc:variable.bgc:description: The third axes of phytophagous beetle species composition based on NMDS ordination scores (used BExIS Id: 16866 v1.1.3; used papers: Müller, J. & Brandl, R. (2009), Doerfler, I. et al. (2018), Roth, N. et al. (2019))

bgc:variable.bgc:name: specnumbers_Lichens
bgc:variable.bgc:description: The log-transformed number of observed lichen species (used BExIS Id: 4460 v1.11.14; used paper: Moning, C. et al. (2009))

bgc:variable.bgc:name: ses_mpd_Lichens
bgc:variable.bgc:description: The standardized effect size of mean phylogenetic distance of lichen assemblage (used BExIS Id: 4460 v1.11.14; used paper: Moning, C. et al. (2009))

bgc:variable.bgc:name: NMDS1_Lichens
bgc:variable.bgc:description: The first axes of lichen species composition based on NMDS ordination scores (used BExIS Id: 4460 v1.11.14; used paper: Moning, C. et al. (2009))

bgc:variable.bgc:name: NMDS2_Lichens
bgc:variable.bgc:description: The second axes of lichen species composition based on NMDS ordination scores (used BExIS Id: 4460 v1.11.14; used paper: Moning, C. et al. (2009))

bgc:variable.bgc:name: specnumbers_Bryophytes
bgc:variable.bgc:description: The log-transformed number of observed bryophyte species (used BExIS Id: 4141 v1.6.8; used paper: Raabe, S. et al. (2010))

bgc:variable.bgc:name: ses_mpd_Bryophytes
bgc:variable.bgc:description: The standardized effect size of mean phylogenetic distance of bryophyte assemblage (used BExIS Id: 4141 v1.6.8; used paper: Raabe, S. et al. (2010))

bgc:variable.bgc:name: NMDS1_Bryophytes
bgc:variable.bgc:description: The first axes of bryophyte species composition based on NMDS ordination scores (used BExIS Id: 4141 v1.6.8; used paper: Raabe, S. et al. (2010))

bgc:variable.bgc:name: NMDS2_Bryophytes

bgc:variable.bgc:name: NMDS3_Bryophytes

bgc:variable.bgc:name: specnumbers_Plants

bgc:variable.bgc:name: ses_mpd_Plants

bgc:papers.bgc:paper: Bässler, C., Müller, J. & Dziock, F. (2010a). Detection of Climate-Sensitive Zones and Identification of Climate Change Indicators: A Case Study from the Bavarian Forest National Park. Folia Geobot., 45, 163–182
Bässler, C., Müller, J., Dziock, F. & Brandl, R. (2010b). Effects of resource availability and climate on the diversity of wood-decaying fungi. J. Ecol., 98, 822–832.

Boch, S., Prati, D., Hessenmöller, D., Schulze, E.-D. & Fischer, M. (2013). Richness of Lichen Species, Especially of Threatened Ones, Is Promoted by Management Methods Furthering Stand Continuity. PLOS ONE, 8, e55461

Doerfler, I., Gossner, M.M., Müller, J., Seibold, S. & Weisser, W.W. (2018). Deadwood enrichment combining integrative and segregative conservation elements enhances biodiversity of multiple taxa in managed forests. Biol. Conserv., 228, 70–78.
Durka, W. & Michalski, S.G. (2012). Daphne: a dated phylogeny of a large European flora for phylogenetically informed ecological analyses. Ecology, 93, 2297–2297.

Jung, K., Kaiser, S., Böhm, S., Nieschulze, J. & Kalko, E.K.V. (2012). Moving in three dimensions: effects of structural complexity on occurrence and activity of insectivorous bats in managed forest stands. J. Appl. Ecol., 49, 523–531.

Lange, M., Türke, M., Pašalić, E., Boch, S., Hessenmöller, D., Müller, J., et al. (2014). Effects of forest management on ground-dwelling beetles (Coleoptera; Carabidae, Staphylinidae) in Central Europe are mainly mediated by changes in forest structure. For. Ecol. Manag., 329, 166–176.

Moning, C., Werth, S., Dziock, F., Bässler, C., Bradtka, J., Hothorn, T., et al. (2009). Lichen diversity in temperate montane forests is influenced by forest structure more than climate. For. Ecol. Manag., 258, 745–751.
Müller, J. & Brandl, R. (2009). Assessing biodiversity by remote sensing in mountainous terrain: the potential of LiDAR to predict forest beetle assemblages. J. Appl. Ecol., 46, 897–905.
Müller, J., Mehr, M., Bässler, C., Fenton, M.B., Hothorn, T., Pretzsch, H., et al. (2012). Aggregative response in bats: prey abundance versus habitat. Oecologia, 169, 673–684.
Müller, J., Moning, C., Bässler, C., Heurich, M. & Brandl, R. (2009). Using airborne laser scanning to model potential abundance and assemblages of forest passerines. Basic Appl. Ecol., 10, 671–681.

Müller J., Boch S., Prati D., Socher S.A., Pommer U., Hessenmöller D., Schall P., Schulze E-D., Fischer M. (2019) Effects of forest management on bryophyte species richness in Central European forests. Forest Ecology and Management 432: 850–859.

Raabe, S., Müller, J., Manthey, M., Dürhammer, O., Teuber, U., Göttlein, A., et al. (2010). Drivers of bryophyte diversity allow implications for forest management with a focus on climate change. For. Ecol. Manag., 260, 1956–1964.

Roth, N., Doerfler, I., Bässler, C., Blaschke, M., Bussler, H., Gossner, M.M., et al. (2019). Decadal effects of landscape-wide enrichment of dead wood on saproxylic organisms in beech forests of different historic management intensity. Divers. Distrib., 25, 430–441.

Wells, K., Böhm, S.M., Boch, S., Fischer, M. & Kalko, E.K.V. (2011). Local and landscape-scale forest attributes differ in their impact on bird assemblages across years in forest production landscapes. Basic Appl. Ecol., 12, 97–106.

Wells, K., O’Hara, R.B., Böhm, S.M., Gockel, S., Hemp, A., Renner, S.C., et al. (2012). Trait-dependent occupancy dynamics of birds in temperate forest landscapes: fine-scale observations in a hierarchical multi-species framework. Anim. Conserv., 15, 626–637.
